debriefing.text: Research indicates that children tend to use shape as the basis for learning categories. For example, if children are shown a giraffe and told that it is called a mupa, and then shown a panda and a same-shaped watering can, and asked to find another mupa, we expect children to select the watering can over the panda because we assume children use shape as the basis for categorizing objects. Although children’s answers can vary, there aren’t any “right” or “wrong” answers to the questions. We are just interested in looking at the average responses from children and we won’t take any specific answers as “good” or “bad”. If you are interested in learning more about this, please see the following experimental paper as here. Thank you again for your participation! Gift cards will be sent within one week of study completion. Please note that we only offer Amazon.com gift card at this time, thanks for your understanding!
debriefing.title: Thank you!

debriefing.text: Research indicates that children tend to use shape as the basis for learning categories. For example, if children are shown a giraffe and told that it is called a mupa, and then shown a panda and a same-shaped watering can, and asked to find another mupa, we expect children to select the watering can over the panda because we assume children use shape as the basis for categorizing objects. Although children’s answers can vary, there aren’t any “right” or “wrong” answers to the questions. We are just interested in looking at the average responses from children and we won’t take any specific answers as “good” or “bad”. If you are interested in learning more about this, please see the following experimental paper as here. Thank you again for your participation! Gift cards will be sent within one week of study completion. Please note that we only offer Amazon.com gift card at this time, thanks for your understanding!
debriefing.title: Thank you!

blocks.title: 1. Overview of what we're doing today

listblocks.text: All together, it will take about 15-20 minutes to finish this study.
Maggie is going to ask you some questions and you can say whatever it is that you think.
There aren’t any right or wrong answers, so just tell Maggie what you think !

blocks.text: Please try playing this sample audio to make sure you'll be able to hear the story.
blocks.title: 2. Adjust your speakers

mediaBlock.warningText: Please try playing the sample audio.

webcamBlocks.title: 3. Make sure we can see you

listblocks.text: Take a look at your webcam view above. Get comfy, and adjust your own position or the computer as needed so both you and your child are visible.

This isn't a Skype call - no one in the lab can see you - but the recorded video of your participation will be sent to the lab to help with data analysis. It's helpful for us to be able to see if your child was pointing or looking confused, for example.

video-consent.risk_statement: There are no expected risks to participation.
video-consent.datause: A research assistant will watch your video and mark down your child's answer to the question at the end of the story, and as well as other information such as interactions between you and your child during the story.
video-consent.payment: After you finish the study, we will email you a $5 Amazon gift card within approximately 5-7 business days. To be eligible for the gift card your child must be in the age range for this study, you need to submit a valid consent statement, and we need to see that there is a child with you. But we will send a gift card even if you do not finish the whole study or we are not able to use your child's data! There are no other direct benefits to you or your child from participating, but we hope you will enjoy the experience.
video-consent.purpose: Research indicates that children tend to use shape as the basis for learning categories. For example, if children are shown an apple and told that it is called a dex, and then shown a balloon and a banana, and asked to find another dex, children will select the balloon over the banana. Findings like this suggest that children use shape as the basis for categorizing objects. In this study, we are interested in developing materials for a categorization task. We want to ensure that children will choose the pictures with the same shape before we move on to the next step.
video-consent.procedures: In this study, your child will meet Maggie, who is curious about what different things are for. Your child will be shown some pictures and be asked which of two items has a particular purpose.

parentTextBlock.text:
Thank you very much for your participation. 
 We look forward to seeing you with more research games in the future.
parentTextBlock.title: For parents

parentTextBlock.text:
Please help keep your child's attention, 
 but don't talk with them about what you think.
parentTextBlock.title: For parents

positioning-config.title: It's time to get your child and get in position!

instructionBlocks.title: Center your webcam if needed
instructionBlocks.text: Make sure the webcam you're using is roughly centered relative to this monitor. This makes it much easier for us to see your video.

image.alt: Example images of using centered external webcam on monitor or built-in webcam on laptop.

instructionBlocks.title: Make sure you can clearly see your child's face
instructionBlocks.text: Take a few moments to get settled and make sure your child's face is clearly visible in the webcam preview to the right. You may need to adjust the webcam angle or turn on a light to make sure his or her face is visible.
The green button down below will start the game. Press the button once you and your child are ready to go!
instructionBlocks.title: When you're ready

parentresponse.title: How should your child provide their answers?

qfeedback.title: We can't see your child's answer if they point to things. It's important that they say their answers out loud.

parentencourage.title: What should you do if you need to repeat the questions to your child?
enum: Rephrase the question using your own words.
Don't rephrase the questions. Read the questions exactly as they appear in the 'For Parents' box.

encfeedback.title: Since we are interested in how subtle changes in language affect categorization, it is VERY IMPORTANT that the questions NOT be rephrased.

parentstopearly.title: During the game, where are the instructions found?
enum: In the 'For Parents' box at the bottom of the screen.

earlyfeedback.title: It is important that you follow the instructions. These are found throughout the game in the 'For Parents' box at the bottom of the screen.

qfeedback.placeholder: Try selecting a different answer above!

encfeedback.placeholder: Try selecting a different answer above!

parentencourage: Rephrase the question using your own words.

earlyfeedback.placeholder: Try selecting a different answer above!

warmup-zulu-intro.pauseText: Game Paused. Press spacebar to resume.

parentTextBlock.text:
For Parents: 
 If you need to repeat the question, please say: 'Can you find another zulu?'. 
 Please remind your child to say 'top' or 'bottom' out loud. 
 Please be sure not to influence your child's decision. Thank you!

first-instructions.introText:
Welcome to the game! Please watch this video to get started. 
(Or you can read the summary to the right if you prefer.)

listblocks.text: Your child does not need to be with you at this point. We will let you know when it is time to get your child.

transcriptBlocks.title: Preview of what your child will see

listblocks.text: In this study, your child will meet Maggie and help her learn puppet language. Your child is going to look at some pictures and then answer some questions. We will ask you (the parent) to avoid discussing with your child until the end of the study. There are no anticipated risks associated with participating.

Because this is an online game, we will check to make sure that your webcam is set up and working properly on the next page, so we can record your child’s answer during the game. We would like to kindly ask you NOT to use earphones or headphones as it may affect the recording.
Following that page, you will be given an opportunity to review the consent information and we will ask that you record a short video of yourself giving consent to participate in this game.
After you are finished with the consent page and questions, you will be provided with more detailed information about what to do during the game and how to get started.

first-instructions.warningText: Please watch the video or read the summary before proceeding.
first-instructions.nextButtonText: I'm ready to make sure my webcam is connected!
first-instructions.title: Game instructions

parentTextBlock.text: Please watch this instruction video carefully before proceeding.

 We look forward to seeing you with more research games in the future.

 but don't talk with them about what you think.
